abstract: This post-hoc analysis of data from a matched cohort study investigated the risk of febrile convulsions (FC) 5–12 days post-first dose of measles-mumps-rubella-varicella vaccine (MMRV) in a low-risk population, compared to measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and varicella (V) vaccines administered separately. The low-risk population excluded children with personal history of FC (Scenario 1) and children with personal or/and family history (≥1 parent/sibling) of FC (Scenario 2). Incidence of FC post-MMRV in Scenario 2 (excluding at risk children) (36.3–49.5/100,000) and post-MMR+V in the whole cohort including children with personal/family history of FC (43.6/100,000) were similar. The risk difference of FC increased by 0.2 case/100,000 in Scenario 1 and decreased by 5.3–8.6 cases/100,000 of vaccinated children in Scenario 2, compared to the whole cohort. The overall risk of FC post-first dose MMRV vaccination could be lowered by administering MMRV only to children with no personal or family history of FC.

body_text.sentence: A matched cohort study conducted in Germany which included data from more than 226,000 children estimated a risk difference of FC of 34.9 per 100,000 children 5–12 days after vaccination with a first dose of MMRV when compared to MMR, 21.8 when compared to MMR+V and 36.4 when compared to the combined MMR/MMR+V cohort [4,12].

body_text.sentence: Should this hypothesis be confirmed, the use of MMRV in a low-risk population could increase vaccine compliance with regards to varicella vaccination and, subsequently lower local reactogenicity due to single injection, at the same time as minimizing the risk of FC, without interfering with current recommendations.
body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: Currently, this is achieved mainly by using a trivalent measles-mumps-rubella vaccine (MMR) and a separate varicella vaccine (V), or by using a tetravalent measles-mumps-rubella-varicella vaccine (MMRV).

body_text.sentence: The tetravalent vaccine has the advantage of reducing the number of injections and potentially extend compliance and coverage; however, an increased risk of fever leading to a higher incidence of febrile convulsions (FC) was observed 5–12 days after first vaccination in children who received MMRV, compared to children who received only MMR or MMR+V separately at the same time [3,4].

body_text.title: Material and methods

body_text.sentence: Here, we present an assumption-based post-hoc analysis of data from this matched cohort study, aiming to investigate whether the presence of a personal or family history of FC would impact the risk of developing FC after a first dose of MMRV, compared to MMR or MMR+V.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Incidence rate estimate of FC after MMRV ranged from 65.3/100,000, when no children were excluded, to 36.3–49.5/100,000, when children with a personal or/and family history of FC were excluded.
body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: The current results regarding the benefit of excluding children with a personal or family history of FC from receiving a first dose of MMRV should be regarded as hypothesis generating.

body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: Table 1 presents the incidence rates of FC for the three different scenarios.
body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: To date, one study was conducted to assess the risk of FC in a low-risk population (excluding children with a personal history of FC, seizure disorder, central nervous system injury, infection or neoplasm, encephalopathy, or a progressive, evolving or unstable neurologic condition) [17].
body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: According to these results, the incidence of FC would be similar if all children, including those with personal or family history of FC, would receive MMR+V, and if only children with no personal or family history of FC would receive MMRV.
body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: The results of this assumption-based analysis suggest that the risk of FC following a first dose of MMRV could be lowered by administering the tetravalent vaccine to children with no personal or family history of FC, and vaccinating children with a personal or family history of FC with separate but concomitant MMR+V vaccines.
body_text.title: Conclusions

body_text.sentence: After exclusion of children with a personal history of FC, a small decrease in risk difference of up to 3.8 was observed when comparing MMRV to MMR or MMR/MMR+V (Supplementary Table 2).

body_text.title: Results and discussion

body_text.sentence: In this post-hoc exploratory analysis, we aimed to explore the risk of FC after a first dose of MMRV in a low-risk population, after excluding children with a personal or/and family history of FC.
body_text.title: Material and methods

body_text.sentence: This analysis re-used data of a matched cohort study in which children received a first dose of either MMRV, MMR, or MMR+V between January 1, 2006 and December 31, 2008 [4].
body_text.title: Material and methods

metadata.title: Impact of history of febrile convulsions on the risk difference of febrile convulsions with the tetravalent measles–mumps–rubella–varicella vaccine: Post-hoc exploratory analysis of results from a matched-cohort study
